titleStmt.title: Grandfather Harran

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: In former times, my grandfather desired a a woman; my late grandfather named Nazzāl.
My grandmother, my late grandmother, she had a tall stature, she was beautiful and tall. She gave birth to six sons and two daughters. But there was a woman who chased him (the grandfather).
He said, “O woman, I want to get married (again).” – “How do you want to get married?” He said, “I want to marry (again).”
The woman, who clung to him, had taken a man before; she had had three children from that man, two sons and a daughter. She was not thingy, two sons and a daughter,

But she had set her mind on my grandfather because she had seen how good he was. And so she wanted my grandfather (as her husband). My grandfather tried to get away from her, but he could not get rid of her.
And then my grandmother said, “O God, the patient!” He said, “I want to get married and it is up to you, if you want to leave or stay.”
She said “By God, I won’t leave my children, my children, six sons and two daughters, I won’t leave them.”
Then my grandfather went ahead and left. Back then my grandfather used to work under the judge (i.e. at the court), he worked in Akçakale.
As for my grandmother, he left her in a place at (the village) of Šiddaw, around fifteen kilometres away. At that time, there was nothing, I mean poverty, there was nothing.
My grandmother took a knife and went out, let’s say, when a donkey had died, when a mare had died in the village. She would go and take it.
She went there and skinned it. She covered her face because of its smell, the smell of carrion.
When it was said that there is a dead donkey at this or that place, she would go there, cover her face, grab the knife and skin it; she would flay the donkey.
She took some salt with her, so she could sprinkle salt on it. She sprinkled flour on it, hung it on a line (to dry it) and sell it.
I mean, this was her job, her profession. There was nothing, there was nothing at that time. If they got sick, when her children got sick there was nothing due to poverty.
When her children got sick, when they were sick she would look around, they make, they look around to they look for a piece of fat.
One day my mother came with my late uncle Maḥmūd; she was going to her stepmother, because my grandfather had married again.

They came and were standing there and were afraid. He she, my mother, she was as old as, let’s say, my uncle Maḥmūd was as old as thingy, as old as Fārūq. And my mother was older than him; as old as, let’s say, thingy, as old as Fāṭōše.
They were afraid, each one was pushing the other, each one said, “You go!”
They were standing from a distance like that, looking and waiting for their father. Maybe their father would get out of the house and go to the prayer.
So they could say, “Dad, our brother is sick, buy us some fat so we can make a thingy, we can make tibrīǧe .
Our brother is sick, he cought a cold; so the sickness would go away from him.” But they would did not dare.
One said, “Hey, you go!” And the other said, “No, you go!” I forgot to mention this.

They were waiting until he would get out of the mosque; maybe he would get out of the mosque and come, he would get out of his house, so they could They did not dare to go to the house because of their stepmother.
Then they did it, they took their thingy and they went: They plucked up their courage, went there and knocked the door.
She opened the door. When she opened the door she said, “What’s the matter with you? Why did you come? What do you want?
Did your mother send you? What do you want?” He said, “Er, er, by God, er.” They were afraid.
“Well our mother has sent us, our mother has sent us, thingy, our brother Aḥmad is not well and our mother has sent us.”
Both of them could not talk, let’s say, their tongue was like that out of their fear of her.
She was standing at the door. She was dark-skinned and black like that; thingy, ugly and scary.
“Our mother has sent us; we want thingy, we thought maybe my father would buy us some fat, we just want a piece of fat.
Our brother is not fine and so we could make him tibrīǧe so that he might get well.”
(She said,) “Aha, apparently your mother has sent you.” Then he (the grandfather) came then and said, “What’s up with you? What do you want from the kids?”
My grandfather appeared and said, “Come!” Then that woman started to scold them.
But he did not listen to her, he was somehow, he had a naïve soul, he was polite. So, he just went ahead and the children were walking behind him.

They had brought a bottle with them to take some paraffin. Weren’t there formerly paraffin lamps? They used to light them like this; they called it paraffin lamp. They would put something like a canister with a lamp in it.
They light it; actually because of the lamp she said, “I want, I want for I want you to buy us some paraffin.
Then (my) late (grandfather), let’s say, she had even taken the bottle from the kids’ hand. Didn’t they want paraffin?
She had taken the bottle from kids’ hand and slapped my late grandfather’s hand. She even scratched his hand.
This old woman. He made his hand, he took the children and went away. He went away, holding his hand, until he had found a bottle for them.
And he put in paraffin for them and then he went and bought them some fat from the butcher like that; some kidney fat. He gave it to them and sent them away saying, “Go!”
They were like (our) Fārūq and Faṭṭaw, they were young. After they had gone away, the old woman did something to him. God forbid!
Then, let’s say, they told it to their mother. After they had gone away, my mother and my told (her) that it this and that had happened.
My uncle was a little bit older, the older one, I mean the firstborn son; he used to work from the between Šiddaw and Akçakale.
Back then, there was a government office where we used to put wheat in . We used to store bring wheat there.
In former times, the government used to take the wheat from the people. And what did the government do with it? They buried it under the ground.
Then my uncle would go when he was still rather young. He used to deal with the wheat, so he could bring some for his siblings.
When he came from there, he would wait and wait until the soldiers throw the food away; after the soldiers had had dinner.
He entered (a place) close to the border and see how the soldiers, how the line of soldiers were throwing the rest of the food away; they were throwing the food away and he would then take away
the one from above (because it’s dirty) and take from inside the food, put it in his apron and bring it to his siblings.
He brought it and threw it to them. They would then get up and eat it like chicks, like that.
And they were living like that; they were living this way, I mean, until my late grandfather heard of them, he heard of them. My late grandfather (the paternal one), my father, he was (his) only kid.
He said, “Since it is a fact that this man had left them.” I mean, they were talking about her (the mother).
They said, I mean, there was poverty and poorness, she had six sons and two daughters. He said, “I want to go and bring her,
I want to go and bring her something, she is our relative, how can I leave her like this? Tomorrow they will be a support to my son, to my children.”
Then my late grandfather went ahead; he and someone from the village, a man. Back then they used to ride on donkeys.
I do not remember any more what they used to ride; I don’t know, maybe they traveled with a cart. They went there, moved them from Šiddaw and brought them to ʕIlle.
When they had brought them to ʕIlle, they took them and left them close to the soldiers, next to the police station.
The soldiers started saying, “Mom, mom, mom, mom!” to my grandmother. I mean, she was a good person, middle aged, I mean, in her fifties, fourties.
“Mom, mom,” they soldiers would call her and they gave her, they used to give her whatever they got of livelihood
from the military: beans, rice, bulgur, whatever came from the government, I mean.
“Mom take! Mom take!” They provided her (with food) and she would wash (the clothes). She said, “Bring me your laundry, if you have one. I will wash it for you.”
She kept on doing the washing for them until her children had grown up, until they were grown-ups. When they had grown up, her children started to do smuggling.
Since they knew her, since they knew these are “my mother’s children” not even the soldiers would say something to them, “because they are my mother’s children.”
When “my mother’s children” would go smuggling, even if they would have been seen by the soldiers, they would go and come back.

When they brought tea (from Syria), they would turn a blind eye on them. But if someone else had gone, they would go ahead and catch them, for sure! Then they started have something. They started to buy gold and they became rich.
Later, one day, let’s say, I did not talk about that: When she made bread
I did not talk about it, I skipped it. Now Ismāʕīn would be angry at me.
He will say, “One time you get talking about thingy, and another time you go back to their poverty?” And therefore I will not talk about that.
Once the officer came. In former times, when people fell in love in the village people would fall in love with other people. There was no shame in that, unlike nowadays.
For instance, someone knew someone’s daughter who was in love with someone. Someone’s daughter was in love with someone, no one would do anything about it.
My mother was beautiful. Then the officer came, And didn’t the officer hear about love and the thing?
He said, “Hey one of the villagers said; I want to ask you, aren’t there any beautiful girls in this village?”
He said, “Of course, there are, the sister of Maḥmūd Aqdoġān is very beautiful.”
Then the officer called after my late uncle and said, “Come here, let me see!” He said, “What is it?”
He said they said, “I have heard that you have a beautiful sister. Go and bring her for me. I want to see how beautiful she really is.
They are talking about her very much, I want to see how beautiful she is.” My late uncle said (to himself), “Now, if I took my sister to him, this son of a dog will become our relative.”
He went to her friend; to their friend in the village; her name was Ṣāfye.
She was black and her snot was this long; she was in the same age (as his sister). They were the same, I mean, they were friends. And he said, “Hey, Ṣāfye!
Come with me, it is this and that, there is the officer.” (She said,) “Hey Maḥmūd, take me, what is with me?” She was black.
He grabbed her hand and took her. When he took her and went to the officer, that one said, “Where is your sister?”
He said, “Here she is!” The officer looked at her and said, “You call this beautiful? Shame on you! What do you know about beauty?”
“This one’s snot is blue and hanging out (of her nose); she is black and look how curly her hair is!”
He said, “This one should be beautiful? May God damn you! Get out of here!” He kicked them out, hahahaha!
